{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18101,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sarcodiotheca gaudichaudii, a type of marine algae, does not require traditional watering like terrestrial plants. Instead, maintaining the appropriate aquatic environment is crucial for its growth. This means ensuring it is submerged in clean, nutrient-rich seawater, ideally mimicking its natural habitat. Regular water changes and monitoring salinity and pH levels are essential. If cultivating this algae in a tank, incorporate a gentle water flow to simulate ocean currents, which aids in nutrient distribution and waste removal, promoting healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sarcodiotheca gaudichaudii thrives in moderate light conditions that replicate natural sea environments. It requires access to either natural sunlight filtered through water or artificial light sources with a spectrum suitable for marine algae. Ensure the light intensity mimics its natural habitat, providing around 6 to 10 hours of light per day. Avoid excessive direct sunlight, as it may lead to overheating and stress, potentially harming the algae. If using artificial lighting, ensure that it is adequately distributed across the growing area to facilitate even growth. Adjust lighting duration and intensity based on algae response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sarcodiotheca gaudichaudii, primarily involves managing its growth to prevent overcrowding in marine aquariums or cultivation tanks. Regularly trim excessive growth with sterilized scissors or shears to keep it within desired limits, promoting healthy growth and aesthetic balance. Remove dead or decaying parts promptly to prevent deterioration of water quality. When trimming, be gentle to avoid damaging the delicate tissues. Pruned sections can often be used for propagation, replanting them in suitable conditions. Regular pruning not only maintains health but also prevents algae from overshadowing other marine species in the ecosystem."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"succulent seaweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North Pacific Coast","Japan"],"other_name":["succulent seaweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Fragmentation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Sarcodiotheca gaudichaudii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19517,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Serruria fasciflora prefers well-drained soil and requires a moderate amount of water. It is important to avoid waterlogging, so ensure that the drainage is excellent. During the growing season in spring and early summer, water the plant deeply once a week. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months to about every two weeks or when the soil is dry to the touch. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s better to err on the side of less water rather than too much. Mulching can help retain moisture and protect the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Serruria fasciflora thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It benefits from at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, which encourages robust growth and a profusion of flowers. If grown in hot inland areas, plants may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. However, insufficient sunlight can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers, so find a balance if some shade is necessary. In coastal areas with milder temperatures, this plant can tolerate full sun throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Serruria fasciflora is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. It is best to prune after the plant has finished flowering, typically in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead or diseased wood and trim back about one-third of the new growth. This practice encourages bushier growth and more flowers in the following season. Avoid cutting into older wood, as this can harm the plant and potentially inhibit bloom production. Regular pruning also helps improve air circulation and reduces the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Pin Spiderhead","description":"Serruria fasciflora or common pin spiderhead is a species of flowering plant in the Proteaceae family. It is a sprawling to upright shrublet of 40 cm to 1 m (1⅓–3⅓ ft) high and about ½ m (1⅔ ft) wide. It has finely divided, upward curving leaves with thread-thin segments and clusters of sweetly scented heads, each consisting of five to seven silvery pink flowers, that may be found year-round, but mostly from May to December. It is...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Common Pin Spiderhead"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Serruria fasciflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18524,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprosma perpusilla, being a hardy alpine species, requires minimal watering. It is adapted to environments where water is not always readily available, so it fares well in well-drained soil with infrequent watering once it's established. Water only when the top 2-3 inches of soil feels dry, as this plant does not tolerate waterlogging. In the winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing the plant to rest, as the growth rate will decrease and it will require less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprosma perpusilla thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is tolerant of a wide range of light conditions but will show the best growth and foliage vibrancy when exposed to several hours of direct sunlight each day. In more shaded environments, it will still grow but may not exhibit its full color potential. Thus, position your plant in an area where it receives ample sunlight while being sheltered from harsh midday sun if the climate is particularly hot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Coprosma perpusilla is minimal, as it generally maintains a compact form. However, to encourage a bushier growth or remove dead or damaged branches, pruning can be done lightly in early spring just before the growing season starts. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and avoid tearing the branches. Any crossed or inward-growing branches that could inhibit light penetration should also be removed to maintain the plant’s shape and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Creeping Coprosma","description":"Coprosma perpusilla, commonly known as creeping coprosma, is a species of flowering plant in the Rubiaceae, or coffee family. It is found in Australia, New Zealand and on some subantarctic islands. The specific epithet comes from the Latin per (very) and pusillus (very small), referring to the growth habit.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Creeping Coprosma"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Coprosma perpusilla"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its active growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. It's important to note that good drainage is crucial, so use a well-draining soil mix and ensure the pot has drainage holes, especially in container setups."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Berzelia abrotanoides thrives in full to partial sunlight. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure it receives adequate light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berzelia abrotanoides is generally minimal but beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Trim back any dead or damaged stems regularly to improve air circulation. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back any leggy growth to promote a more compact form. When pruning, make clean cuts just above a pair of leaves or a node to encourage new branching. Sterilize pruning tools before use to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Redleg Kolkol","description":"Berzelia abrotanoides, commonly known as redlegs, is a species of flowering plant in the family Bruniaceae native to the Western Cape region of South Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19420,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aspalathus ciliaris, a member of the Fabaceae family, prefers well-drained soil and should not be over-watered. It's essential to allow the top layer of the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil is moist but not waterlogged. In contrast, reduce the watering frequency during its dormancy period in winter. Overwatering can lead to root rot, a common issue in poorly drained conditions. Monitoring the moisture level in the soil can help in maintaining appropriate watering habits."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aspalathus ciliaris thrives in full sun, meaning it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure enhances flowering and overall vigor. For indoor planting or in regions with limited sunlight, supplementing with grow lights can be an alternative solution. Ensuring adequate sunlight supports the plant's photosynthesis process and encourages robust growth. If grown in excessively shady areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, compromising its ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aspalathus ciliaris encourages bushier growth and helps maintain its shape. The best time to prune is during its dormant period, typically in late winter or early spring. Remove any dead or diseased wood by cutting back to healthy tissue. It's recommended to trim back any overly long stems to promote a more compact growth habit. By selectively thinning out branches, you can increase air circulation within the plant, helping to prevent diseases. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make neat cuts and minimize potential plant stress or damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringe Capegorse","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Fringe Capegorse"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aspalathus ciliaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In darker locations, supplement with artificial light to ensure the plant gets enough light to maintain its lush foliage. Rotating the plant occasionally will help promote even growth and prevent it from leaning towards the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Leea guineensis is generally light and should be done to maintain a desired shape and to remove dead or damaged leaves. Trim back any leggy or overgrown stems during the growing season to encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Focus on removing any crossing branches and thinning the canopy to allow sunlight and air to penetrate. This plant can also be lightly pruned in the summer to maintain its shape. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season to prevent stress. Regular pruning will help maintain a bushy and compact form, ideal for ornamental purposes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Strawberry dogwood","description":"Cornus capitata is a species of dogwood known by the common names Bentham's cornel, evergreen dogwood, Himalayan flowering dogwood, and Himalayan strawberry-tree. When formulated as a biopesticide, it is usually applied in a way that ensures it remains moist enough for the spores to be viable, such as mixing it with water right before application. It is a fungus, and like many fungi, it can grow well in various lighting conditions, typically in shaded or indirect light environments. When applied as a biopesticide, it is more crucial to ensure it is in an environment conducive to fungal growth, which means maintaining appropriate temperature and humidity levels, rather than focusing on sunlight exposure, which does not significantly affect this particular type of organism."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Beauveria bassiana, as it is a fungus used in agricultural settings rather than a plant that undergoes growth requiring shaping or removal of stems and leaves. Essentially, there is no need to prune this fungus. The focus is on maintaining optimal conditions for its growth and efficacy when used in microbial pest control formulations, ensuring that its spores can proliferate and function effectively in controlling insect populations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Icing sugar fungus","description":"Beauveria bassiana is a fungus that grows naturally in soils throughout the world and acts as a parasite on various arthropod species, causing white muscardine disease; it thus belongs to the entomopathogenic fungi. It is being used as a biological insecticide to control a number of pests such as termites, thrips, whiteflies, aphids and different beetles. During the growing season, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. During dry spells or high temperatures, increase watering frequency to compensate for increased evaporation. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy and requires less moisture. Always aim to water at the base of the plant to prevent fungal diseases on the leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentiana cruciata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with very hot summers, provide some afternoon shade to protect the plant from intense heat and potential scorching. If planted in partial shade, make sure it still receives ample sunlight for vigorous blooming. Bear in mind that low light conditions may lead to reduced flower production. Position the plant in a spot where it can bask in morning sun while being shielded from intense afternoon rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gentiana cruciata should generally be minimal. After flowering, you can deadhead the flowers to encourage a tidy appearance and potentially extend the blooming period. Remove withered or yellow leaves to maintain its aesthetic appeal and overall health. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring to prepare the plant for new growth. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this could damage the plant. Consistently check for any dead or damaged stems and remove them to prevent disease and pest infiltration."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cross Gentian","description":"Gentiana cruciata, the star gentian or cross gentian, is a herbaceous perennial flowering plant in the Gentianaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Cross Gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gentiana cruciata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18525,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprosma pseudocuneata prefers moderate watering. It is important to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings, as this plant does not thrive in waterlogged conditions. Therefore, watering once a week should be sufficient, adjusting for climate and season. During the growing season, ensure the soil is kept consistently moist but not soggy. In winter, reduce watering, allowing the top couple of inches of soil to dry out before re-watering. Always use well-draining soil to prevent root rot. Monitoring the plant’s condition will help in adjusting the frequency appropriately."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprosma pseudocuneata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant foliage, place this plant in a location where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Too much shade can result in leggy growth and less vibrant colors, especially for those varieties known for their vivid foliage. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Balance is key, and observing the plant’s response will help in finding the right spot that offers a healthy mix of sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coprosma pseudocuneata is generally minimal but beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. The best time for pruning is in early spring before the growing season starts. Use sharp, clean pruners to trim back any overgrown stems, focusing on dead, damaged, or crossing branches. Regularly removing spent flowers can also channel energy back into the plant, promoting healthier growth. Avoid heavy pruning, as excessive cutting back can stress the plant. However, periodic light pruning maintains an attractive shape and encourages lush foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Coprosma pseudocuneata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19617,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vachellia erioloba, also known as the camel thorn tree, is highly drought-tolerant and should be watered sparingly. During the growing season, which is typically in spring and summer, the plant can be watered moderately but ensure the soil is allowed to dry out between waterings. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly, only providing enough moisture to keep the soil from completely drying out. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to maintain well-draining soil conditions to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vachellia erioloba thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow well. It's adapted to the harsh sunlight of arid regions, so it performs best in environments where it can receive abundant natural light throughout the day. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and flowering occur under full sun exposure. Ensure the plant is positioned in a location where it won't be overshadowed by larger trees or structures, as this can lead to leggy growth and reduced vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vachellia erioloba should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the plant's health. Additionally, remove any branches that cross or rub against each other to prevent damage. If necessary, shape the canopy for aesthetic reasons or to improve air circulation by thinning out dense growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize potential injury or infection to the tree. Pruning should be done sparingly to maintain the tree's natural form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Camel Thorn","description":"Vachellia erioloba (camel thorn, giraffe thorn) is a tree of southern Africa in the family Fabaceae. Its preferred habitat is the deep dry sandy soils in parts of South Africa, Botswana, the western areas of Zimbabwe and Namibia. It is also native to Angola, south-west Mozambique, Zambia and Swaziland. The tree was first described by Ernst Heinrich Friedrich Meyer and Johann Franz Drège in 1836. The camel thorn is a protected tree in South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Camel Thorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia erioloba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18626,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aciphylla scott-thomsonii, like many alpine or mountain plants, is adapted to environments with well-drained soils and moderate moisture levels. It benefits from infrequent, deep watering that ensures the soil is thoroughly moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, particularly in heavier soil mixes. Allow the top few inches of soil to dry out between watering sessions. In cooler climates or when the plant is not actively growing, reduce the frequency of watering to prevent excess moisture in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aciphylla scott-thomsonii thrives best in full sunlight, emulating its native alpine habitat. Providing a location that receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day ensures its optimal growth and development. The plant is well-adapted to high-light environments and may struggle or produce less defined foliage patterns if grown in excessive shade. It is suitable for rock gardens and sunny, well-ventilated spots in the garden. Protect from harsh afternoon sun in hotter climates to prevent foliage scorch and stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Aciphylla scott-thomsonii is generally minimal, as it's a slow-growing, architectural plant noted for its spiky foliage. Old or dead foliage can be carefully removed to encourage new growth and maintain plant health, but it's crucial to use clean, sharp tools to avoid damage or disease spread. Avoid pruning during colder months when growth slows. The plant's natural structure is attractive, so pruning should be aimed at cleaning rather than reshaping. After flowering, spent flower stalks can be cut back to conserve the plant's energy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Aciphylla scott-thomsonii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19813,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lachenalia punctata, a bulbous plant native to South Africa, requires careful watering. During the growing season, water the plant regularly but allow the soil to dry out slightly between watering. Overwatering can lead to bulb rot, especially in water-retentive soils. It's crucial to reduce watering once flowering ends, typically at the end of spring or early summer, as the plant enters dormancy. During dormancy, the plant should be kept dry. The general advice is to provide just enough moisture to prevent shriveling of the bulbs but not enough to encourage growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lachenalia punctata thrives in environments with plenty of bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, especially during the morning or late afternoon. If the plant is grown indoors, position it near a window with filtered light to avoid the harsh midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. When outdoors, it does well in lightly shaded areas that receive a few hours of direct sunlight per day. Ensuring the plant receives sufficient light will aid in flower production and overall health, while too much shade can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lachenalia punctata is relatively straightforward due to its seasonal nature. After the flowering season, you should remove spent flowers to prevent seed formation and to tidy the plant. This process helps direct energy back into the bulb for the next growing season. Once the foliage begins to yellow and dry out, it can also be trimmed back as the plant enters dormancy. It's crucial not to cut the foliage while it remains green since it is photosynthesizing and feeding the bulb. Regularly check for any damaged or diseased leaves and remove them immediately."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dotted Viooltjie","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Dotted Viooltjie"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Offsets"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Lachenalia punctata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18823,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Korthalsella salicornioides, also known as jointed mistletoe, is a semi-parasitic plant, which means its watering needs are generally lesser compared to non-parasitic plants. It derives some moisture from its host plant, but if grown in a container, water sparingly, just enough to keep the soil lightly moist. Overwatering can easily lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly before watering again. During its growing season, a bit more water can be tolerated, but always ensure that the soil has excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Korthalsella salicornioides thrives in partial to full shade conditions, as it typically grows on the shaded parts of its host plants in its native habitat. It is not a fan of direct, harsh sunlight which can scorch its foliage. If cultivated indoors or in a container, place it in a spot where it receives indirect light or filtered sunlight. If outdoors, aim for a location under a larger plant or shaded corner that simulates its natural environment. Providing the right amount of light ensures its optimal growth and health, preventing any light-related stress or damage to the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Korthalsella salicornioides is not overly complex. Given that this plant is semi-parasitic and relies on another host, minimal pruning is usually needed. However, to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth, occasionally trim back overly long stems or any that appear dead or unhealthy. Pruning is best done in the growing season to help the plant recover more quickly, using sterilized pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease. Be gentle to avoid damaging the host plant, if applicable, and take care not to remove too much foliage, which can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Korthalsella salicornioides or dwarf mistletoe is an endemic parasitic plant in New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand","Australia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Korthalsella salicornioides"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19320,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gladiolus permeabilis requires moderate watering to thrive. It’s best to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, water the plant once or twice a week, ensuring the top inch of the soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. Reduce watering during the dormant period, typically in winter, when the plant is not actively growing. Always use well-draining soil to avoid water accumulation, and consider the local climate conditions when adjusting your watering schedule to prevent either under or overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gladiolus permeabilis thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Such exposure ensures vigorous growth and vibrant blooms. If planted in partial shade, the plant may become leggy, with fewer flowers. Choose a garden location that receives ample morning sunlight and some afternoon shade to provide a slight reprieve from the intense midday sun. In areas with extremely hot climates, providing partial shade during peak sunlight hours can help prevent leaf scorch and keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gladiolus permeabilis typically involves removing spent flowers and dead foliage to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. After the flowers have faded, cut the flower stalks back to about an inch above the ground to prevent seed formation, allowing the plant to focus its energy on storing nutrients for the next growing season. In the late fall or early winter, once the foliage has died back naturally, trim it away to tidy up the plant and garden area. Ensure your pruning tools are clean to avoid transmitting diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Partridge Pypie","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Partridge Pypie"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Corms"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gladiolus permeabilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18329,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhodophiala bifida, commonly known as the oxblood lily, requires careful watering to thrive. Overwatering can lead to bulb rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. Once the flowering season ends and the foliage begins to wither, reduce watering to allow the plant to enter its dormant period through late fall and winter. During dormancy, the plant requires minimal water, just enough to prevent the soil from completely drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhodophiala bifida thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for vibrant blooms. Full sun is preferred, especially in regions with cooler climates, to ensure adequate flowering. In hotter areas, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from intense heat. If planted in partial shade, ensure it receives morning sun to stimulate blooming. Observing the balance between sunlight and shade is crucial to ensure the plant develops vibrant and healthy flowers each season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhodophiala bifida is minimal and mainly involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. When storing, ensure any cut or damaged sections are addressed to maintain freshness and quality for consumption."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Western cauliflower mushroom","description":"Sparassis (also known as cauliflower mushroom) is a genus of parasitic and saprobic mushrooms characterised by their unique shape and appearance. It can tolerate partial shade but should be shielded from direct midday sun, especially in hotter climates, to prevent leaf scorch. The plant benefits from dappled sunlight, similar to what it would receive in its natural understory habitat. If kept indoors, ensure it gets enough light by supplementing with a grow light during the darker months to maintain its growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Trochodendron aralioides should be done minimally since it naturally has a pleasing shape. Prune primarily to remove any dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health. You can also prune lightly to shape the plant or to control its size in spring just before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts. Avoid pruning heavily as this can stress the plant and lead to reduced growth. Regular pruning is not necessary unless shaping is desired, and always sanitize tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cartwheel Tree","description":"Trochodendron aralioides, sometimes colloquially called \"wheel tree\", is a flowering plant and the sole living species in the genus Trochodendron, which also includes several extinct species. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can reduce the number of blooms and berries it produces. They can tolerate full shade, though blooms may be less profuse. Avoid overly sunny and hot locations, particularly during the afternoon, as excessive heat and light can stress and dry out the plant. These adaptable plants are often successfully grown under deciduous trees where filtered light reaches the plants throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hyacinthoides × massartiana involves mainly cutting back the flower stems once they have completed blooming. Deadheading spent blooms helps to divert energy back to the bulb, promoting healthier growth. Do not remove the leaves while they are still green since the foliage helps in photosynthesis, nourishing the bulb for the next year's growth. Leaves should naturally wither and yellow before being pruned back at the base. Removing dead foliage also helps to maintain a tidy appearance and ensures better health of the plant in the long term."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Hybrid bluebell","description":"Hyacinthoides × massartiana is a hybrid species produced by crosses between the common bluebell, H. non-scripta and the Spanish bluebell, H. hispanica. Mimicking natural woodland conditions will best support this symbiotic relationship."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Suillellus amygdalinus is not a plant but a fungus, it does not require traditional pruning. Prune trees to promote good air circulation and light penetration. Remove dead or diseased branches from the trees, as maintaining tree health is crucial for mycorrhizal fungi like Suillellus amygdalinus, which rely on robust tree hosts for sustenance. Always use sanitized pruning tools to prevent any potential spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Liver Bolete","description":"Suillellus amygdalinus (formerly Boletus amygdalinus) is a fungus of the bolete family found in western North America. However, in winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to become almost dry. Always use well-drained soil to prevent standing water around the roots. When grown indoors, place the plant near a window that receives plenty of indirect light. Adjust the plant's position if you notice any sunburned leaves or stunted growth due to insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lachnaea grandiflora helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. It is best to prune in early spring just before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged growth to promote healthy new development. During the growing season, keep the soil evenly moist by watering whenever the top inch feels dry to the touch. In contrast, during dormancy or non-growing seasons, reduce watering significantly to prevent root rot, allowing the soil to become slightly drier between waterings. Adjust watering frequency based on the climate and the plant's specific environmental conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Myosotis sparsiflora grows best in partial shade to full sun. It enjoys morning sun with some afternoon shade, which helps protect it from the intense midday heat. In cooler climates, providing full sun can help the plant thrive and produce more blooms. However, in hotter regions, offering partial shade, especially during the peak of the afternoon, will benefit growth and prevent the leaves from scorching. Ensure it receives at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal health and flowering, adjusting based on its specific growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myosotis sparsiflora primarily involves removing dead or yellowing leaves and spent blooms to encourage new growth and prolong flowering. Perform light pruning during the growing season to keep the plant tidy and prevent it from becoming too leggy. It is crucial not to overwater this plant, as it is susceptible to root rot in overly damp conditions. However, during the hottest part of summer, providing some light shade in the afternoon can protect it from leaf scorch, particularly if the plant is in a pot or container. If light levels are too low, the plant might become leggy and flower production can diminish. An outdoor location with well-circulated air and plenty of sunlight is ideal for its optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helichrysum patulum helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Trim back any dead or wilted stems and leaves with sterilized pruning shears. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to promote further blooming throughout its flowering season. This can be done by snipping the flower heads off at their base when they start to fade. For more significant pruning, wait until the late winter or early spring just before the growth phase begins. This is when the plant is dormant, making it less stressful on the plant to undergo pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Honey Everlasting","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Honey Everlasting"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Helichrysum patulum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the soil to dry moderately between waterings to prevent root rot. Water thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the active growing season in spring and summer, it may require more frequent watering, but it's essential not to overwater as this plant is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Adjusting the plant's position according to seasonal light changes can promote healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gentiana arisanensis typically involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and encourage reblooming. Deadheading, or trimming off the faded flowers, promotes more vigorous growth and prevents the plant from directing energy into seed production. In early spring, lightly trim back the foliage to shape the plant and remove any winter damage. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid introducing disease. For taller varieties, you can also prune the main trunk to control height, but this should be done with care, ensuring to dry the cut properly to prevent infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Weak-leaf Yucca","description":"Yucca flaccida, commonly called Adam's needle or weak-leaf yucca, is a species of flowering plant in the asparagus family (Asparagaceae). If grown indoors or in an atypical setting, you can occasionally mist this lichen lightly with water, especially during dry periods, to simulate dew or rain it would naturally encounter. However, avoid overwatering or submerging it, as lichens can be sensitive to excessive moisture, which leads to decay or mold."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rusavskia elegans thrives in conditions where it receives filtered sunlight or partial shade. This lichen is adapted to environments that are not exposed to direct, harsh sunlight for prolonged periods, as it may desiccate or become sunburned. If cultivated, it should be placed in an area that replicates its natural habitat, such as a shaded rock or tree environment with dappled sunlight. Indoor cultivation should involve indirect light, such as from a north or east-facing window. Overexposure to sunlight should be avoided to protect its health and vibrant coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Rusavskia elegans, a lichen, is minimal and typically only necessary if maintaining a specific size or shape is desired in a cultivated setting. However, if pruning is necessary, it should be done gently with sterile scissors or garden shears, taking care not to damage the lichen's body. Water the plant thoroughly whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. It's essential to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, it may require more frequent watering as it actively grows. In contrast, reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows. It's always better to underwater slightly than to overwater, as this species is somewhat drought-tolerant. Using tepid, filtered water can help avoid mineral buildup in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Seemannia sylvatica thrives in bright but indirect sunlight. Ideally, it should be placed in a location where it can receive filtered light or moderate light for the majority of the day. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, can scorch its leaves, so it's beneficial to provide some shading. If kept indoors, a spot near a north or east-facing window is suitable. In lower light conditions, the plant can survive but may not flower as prolifically. It’s important to monitor the plant's response and adjust its location as needed to maximize its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Seemannia sylvatica generally involves removing spent flowers and any unwanted or leggy growth to encourage bushier growth and prolong flowering. This should be done throughout the growing season. Using a pair of sharp, sterilized scissors or pruning shears, cut back the stems just above a node to stimulate new growth. Pruning also helps in maintaining a tidy appearance and preventing any pest infestations. Removing dead or damaged leaves can also promote better airflow around the plant, reducing the risk of disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19626,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clematis sibirica requires consistent moisture to thrive, especially during the growing season. It is essential to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on the weather and soil conditions. The soil should be well-draining to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool. During dry spells or hot summer months, increase watering to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Reduce watering slightly in winter when the plant is dormant, but do not allow the roots to dry out entirely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis sibirica thrives in locations where it can receive ample sunlight. Ideally, plant it in a spot where it can enjoy full sun to partial shade. At least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day is preferred, which encourages robust growth and optimal flowering. However, the base and roots of the plant prefer to be shaded and kept cool. Using mulch or low growing companion plants to shade the root area can help achieve this balance. In extremely hot climates, providing afternoon shade will prevent the foliage from scorching. Adjust based on local climate conditions for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis sibirica is beneficial for promoting healthy growth and abundant flowering. It is considered a Group 1 clematis, which means it flowers on the previous year's growth. Prune after flowering, typically in late winter or early spring. Remove dead, damaged, or weak stems to open up the plant for better air circulation and sunlight penetration. Avoid hard pruning as it could reduce the flowering for the upcoming season. Focus on trimming back any overlong or tangled stems to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage the plant to produce new shoots for the following year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Siberia","Mongolia","China"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Clematis wilt"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Clematis sibirica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rich","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the pot has proper drainage to avoid waterlogging, and use lukewarm water to prevent shocking the roots. Misting the leaves occasionally can also help maintain humidity, as this plant enjoys a moist environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Puka thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate some direct sunlight, particularly in the early morning or late afternoon. It is essential to avoid prolonged exposure to harsh midday sun as it can scorch the leaves. In low-light situations, Meryta sinclairii may become leggy and less vibrant, so it's crucial to find a suitable spot with adequate light levels."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Meryta sinclairii should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any unhealthy or dead branches. Adjust as needed to mimic under-canopy forest conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Scytinium palmatum does not require traditional pruning like higher plants, as it is a lichen. Regularly removing dead leaves prevents pests and disease from taking hold. In general, agaves do not need much pruning overall. Also, remove any baby plants or \"pups\" if you do not want the plant to spread. Remember to wear gloves and protective clothing to avoid irritation from the sap."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mitis Century Plant","description":"Agave mitis is a plant species native to the Mexican states of Hidalgo, Tamaulipas and San Luis Potosí, referred to as Agave celsii in many publications.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Mitis Century Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Offset Division","Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agave mitis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can help protect it from intense sunlight, which may scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window with ample light, or supplement with grow lights if natural light is insufficient. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even exposure on all sides. Ensure the chosen location has ample light to keep the plant vigorous and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Brunia noduliflora should be done after the flowering period to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged branches. Focus on trimming the tips to shape the plant or to control its size in landscape settings. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19420,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aspalathus ciliaris, a member of the Fabaceae family, prefers well-drained soil and should not be over-watered. It's essential to allow the top layer of the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil is moist but not waterlogged. In contrast, reduce the watering frequency during its dormancy period in winter. Overwatering can lead to root rot, a common issue in poorly drained conditions. Monitoring the moisture level in the soil can help in maintaining appropriate watering habits."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aspalathus ciliaris thrives in full sun, meaning it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure enhances flowering and overall vigor. For indoor planting or in regions with limited sunlight, supplementing with grow lights can be an alternative solution. Ensuring adequate sunlight supports the plant's photosynthesis process and encourages robust growth. If grown in excessively shady areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, compromising its ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aspalathus ciliaris encourages bushier growth and helps maintain its shape. The best time to prune is during its dormant period, typically in late winter or early spring. Remove any dead or diseased wood by cutting back to healthy tissue. It's recommended to trim back any overly long stems to promote a more compact growth habit. By selectively thinning out branches, you can increase air circulation within the plant, helping to prevent diseases. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make neat cuts and minimize potential plant stress or damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringe Capegorse","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Fringe Capegorse"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aspalathus ciliaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19319,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Disa cornuta prefers consistently moist conditions, so it's important to water it regularly to prevent the substrate from drying out completely. It's best to use distilled or rainwater as these plants are sensitive to water quality. Water them thoroughly and ensure good drainage to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Reduce watering slightly in winter when the plant's growth slows down, but never let the medium dry out completely. Importantly, maintain high humidity around the plant to replicate its natural growing conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Disa cornuta thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It is important to avoid direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, as this can scorch the delicate leaves. Provide filtered light by placing it near a bright window with a sheer curtain or in a spot that receives dappled shade. If growing indoors, it might benefit from some exposure to a cool growing light to supplement natural light, especially in less sunny environments. Consistent light levels will support healthy growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Disa cornuta is minimal and primarily focused on removing dead or diseased foliage and old flower spikes after blooming to encourage fresh growth. As new shoots emerge, ensure they are not overcrowded to allow for good air circulation, which helps prevent fungal diseases. Trim back any brown or yellow leaves with sterilized scissors to keep the plant looking tidy and healthy. Consistent light grooming and removing of any old leaves will help the plant invest energy into producing new growth and flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Disa","description":"Disa cornuta is a species of orchid found from Zimbabwe to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Golden Disa"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Disa cornuta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18227,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cornus capitata, or the Himalayan dogwood, requires moderate watering. During its growing season in spring and summer, ensure the soil is kept consistently moist but not soggy. This plant prefers well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. In the cooler months of fall and winter, reduce the watering frequency as the plant’s water needs decrease. Always check the topsoil; if it feels dry to the touch about an inch down, it’s time to water. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cornus capitata thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least four to six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate some shade, insufficient light may result in poor flowering and leggy growth. In hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. If planted in a container, consider moving it to different locations seasonally to ensure it receives the appropriate amount of sunlight. Ensure it is placed in a spot that meets its sunlight needs for robust health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cornus capitata is essential to maintain its shape, encourage healthy growth, and remove any dead or diseased wood. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Focus on removing any crossing branches and thinning the canopy to allow sunlight and air to penetrate. This plant can also be lightly pruned in the summer to maintain its shape. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season to prevent stress. Regular pruning will help maintain a bushy and compact form, ideal for ornamental purposes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Strawberry dogwood","description":"Cornus capitata is a species of dogwood known by the common names Bentham's cornel, evergreen dogwood, Himalayan flowering dogwood, and Himalayan strawberry-tree. It is native to the low-elevation woodlands of the Himalayas in China, India, and surrounding nations and it is naturalized in parts of Australia and New Zealand. It is grown elsewhere as an ornamental. This is an evergreen tree growing to 12 meters in height and width. The leaves are gray-green and pale and","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Himalaya","China"],"other_name":["Strawberry dogwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cornus capitata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19712,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Greeneocharis circumscissa, commonly known as Desert Plantain, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. During its growing season, water the plant deeply once every two to three weeks, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant is dormant. Make sure to use well-draining soil and a pot with drainage holes to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Overwatering should be avoided as it can stress the plant and lead to health issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Greeneocharis circumscissa thrives best in full sunlight. It requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its compact form and vibrant foliage. If indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. Inadequate sunlight might lead to leggy growth and pale leaves. However, in particularly hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can prevent scorching. Ensure that the plant is not kept in low-light conditions for extended periods to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Greeneocharis circumscissa is generally minimal. Remove any dead or damaged leaves by cutting them back to the base, which helps maintain the plant's appearance and health. This plant does not require extensive shaping, but if it appears leggy or overgrown, light pruning to encourage bushier growth can be beneficial. Prune during the plant's dormant period to minimize stress, and use clean, sharp tools to prevent infections. Avoid excessive pruning, as the plant can be sensitive to over-cutting."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cushion Cryptantha","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Cushion Cryptantha"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Greeneocharis circumscissa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19812,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Beauveria bassiana is a fungus rather than a typical plant, and as such, it does not require regular watering in the way plants do. When formulated as a biopesticide, it is usually applied in a way that ensures it remains moist enough for the spores to be viable, such as mixing it with water right before application. The main priority is to maintain adequate humidity in the environment where the fungus is applied, as moisture facilitates spore germination and infection of the target insects."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Beauveria bassiana itself doesn't require sunlight to grow and thrive. It is a fungus, and like many fungi, it can grow well in various lighting conditions, typically in shaded or indirect light environments. When applied as a biopesticide, it is more crucial to ensure it is in an environment conducive to fungal growth, which means maintaining appropriate temperature and humidity levels, rather than focusing on sunlight exposure, which does not significantly affect this particular type of organism."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Beauveria bassiana, as it is a fungus used in agricultural settings rather than a plant that undergoes growth requiring shaping or removal of stems and leaves. Essentially, there is no need to prune this fungus. The focus is on maintaining optimal conditions for its growth and efficacy when used in microbial pest control formulations, ensuring that its spores can proliferate and function effectively in controlling insect populations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Icing sugar fungus","description":"Beauveria bassiana is a fungus that grows naturally in soils throughout the world and acts as a parasite on various arthropod species, causing white muscardine disease; it thus belongs to the entomopathogenic fungi. It is being used as a biological insecticide to control a number of pests such as termites, thrips, whiteflies, aphids and different beetles. Its use in the control of bedbugs and malaria-transmitting mosquitos is under investigation.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","India","Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Icing sugar fungus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Beauveria bassiana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18132,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bougainvillea × buttiana requires careful watering practices as it prefers slightly dry conditions. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially during less active growing seasons. During the growing season, from spring to fall, water thoroughly and allow excess to drain away. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. In winter, reduce the frequency of watering, only watering enough to prevent the plant from completely drying out. It's crucial to provide good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which the plant does not tolerate well."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bougainvillea × buttiana thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 5-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to bloom abundantly. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight will result in fewer blooms and a less vibrant display. This plant is well-suited for outdoor spaces where it can receive ample light, such as a sunny patio or garden area. Ensure that it is placed in a location where it is exposed to direct sunlight for most of the day for optimal growth and flowering performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Bougainvillea × buttiana is essential to promote growth and to keep the plant looking tidy. Pruning is best done in early spring or after each blooming cycle. Cut back long, overgrown stems to maintain the desired shape and remove any dead or damaged wood. Pruning also encourages the plant to become bushier and increases blooming potential. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to ensure clean cuts and minimize plant stress. Additionally, regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage new blooms throughout the flowering season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"garden bougainvillea","description":"Bougainvillea × buttiana is a flowering plant, a garden hybrid of Bougainvillea glabra and Bougainvillea peruviana.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["garden bougainvillea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Caterpillars","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Bougainvillea × buttiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18625,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acianthus sinclairii, also known as the heart-leaved orchid, prefers a moist environment but should not be waterlogged. Water the plant moderately, allowing the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly before watering again. During its active growing season, usually in late winter to spring, increase watering to maintain consistent soil moisture. However, during its dormancy period, reduce watering significantly, only providing enough moisture to prevent the soil from completely drying out. Be cautious to avoid water stagnation which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acianthus sinclairii thrives in shaded to semi-shaded environments. It mimics its natural habitat under the forest canopy, where it receives filtered or dappled sunlight. Direct sunlight can be too intense, potentially scorching the delicate leaves. Ideally, place the plant where it can receive diffuse light, such as near north-facing windowsills or under artificial grow lights if natural light is insufficient. If outdoors, ensure that it is protected from direct midday sun by situating it under taller plants or using shade cloth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Acianthus sinclairii is minimal and mostly revolves around removing spent flowers and dead or yellowing leaves to encourage healthy growth. After the flowering phase, trim away old flower spikes to redirect energy back to the plant. Ensure to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Minimal leaf removal is required unless they are damaged or diseased. This light maintenance helps maintain the plant's aesthetic appeal and promotes better air circulation around its base."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pixie cap","description":"Acianthus sinclairii, commonly known as pixie cap or heart-leaf orchid, is a flowering plant in the orchid family Orchidaceae and is endemic to New Zealand. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19616,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ursinia paleacea prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. It is essential to allow the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot, as this plant is somewhat drought-tolerant. Overwatering should be avoided, especially in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. During the active growing season, usually spring and summer, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months as the plant requires less moisture. Regular watering promoting drainage will help ensure this plant thrives."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ursinia paleacea thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Specific to its native climates, this plant is adapted to bright and sunny locations, which support its vigor and flowering. In shadier locations, the plant might exhibit reduced flowering and a leggy growth habit due to insufficient light. If you're growing Ursinia paleacea indoors, make sure it's placed in a sunny windowsill or consider supplementing with grow lights to mimic the sun exposure it would naturally receive outdoors for optimal health and bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ursinia paleacea primarily involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth and prolonged blooming. Regular deadheading, or the removal of faded flowers, will stimulate the plant to produce more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Cut back any overgrown stems after flowering to keep the plant compact and bushy. If the plant starts to look leggy or untidy, more substantial pruning can be done in early spring before the growth season begins, taking care to not cut too much so the plant can regenerate effectively."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fire Paraseed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Fire Paraseed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ursinia paleacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18102,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gentiana cruciata, also known as Cross Gentian, prefers well-drained, moderately moist soils. During the growing season, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. During dry spells or high temperatures, increase watering frequency to compensate for increased evaporation. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy and requires less moisture. Always aim to water at the base of the plant to prevent fungal diseases on the leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentiana cruciata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with very hot summers, provide some afternoon shade to protect the plant from intense heat and potential scorching. If planted in partial shade, make sure it still receives ample sunlight for vigorous blooming. Bear in mind that low light conditions may lead to reduced flower production. Position the plant in a spot where it can bask in morning sun while being shielded from intense afternoon rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gentiana cruciata should generally be minimal. After flowering, you can deadhead the flowers to encourage a tidy appearance and potentially extend the blooming period. Remove withered or yellow leaves to maintain its aesthetic appeal and overall health. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring to prepare the plant for new growth. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this could damage the plant. Consistently check for any dead or damaged stems and remove them to prevent disease and pest infiltration."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cross Gentian","description":"Gentiana cruciata, the star gentian or cross gentian, is a herbaceous perennial flowering plant in the Gentianaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Cross Gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gentiana cruciata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18525,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprosma pseudocuneata prefers moderate watering. It is important to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings, as this plant does not thrive in waterlogged conditions. Therefore, watering once a week should be sufficient, adjusting for climate and season. During the growing season, ensure the soil is kept consistently moist but not soggy. In winter, reduce watering, allowing the top couple of inches of soil to dry out before re-watering. Always use well-draining soil to prevent root rot. Monitoring the plant’s condition will help in adjusting the frequency appropriately."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprosma pseudocuneata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant foliage, place this plant in a location where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Too much shade can result in leggy growth and less vibrant colors, especially for those varieties known for their vivid foliage. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Balance is key, and observing the plant’s response will help in finding the right spot that offers a healthy mix of sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coprosma pseudocuneata is generally minimal but beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. The best time for pruning is in early spring before the growing season starts. Use sharp, clean pruners to trim back any overgrown stems, focusing on dead, damaged, or crossing branches. Regularly removing spent flowers can also channel energy back into the plant, promoting healthier growth. Avoid heavy pruning, as excessive cutting back can stress the plant. However, periodic light pruning maintains an attractive shape and encourages lush foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Coprosma pseudocuneata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19617,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vachellia erioloba, also known as the camel thorn tree, is highly drought-tolerant and should be watered sparingly. During the growing season, which is typically in spring and summer, the plant can be watered moderately but ensure the soil is allowed to dry out between waterings. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly, only providing enough moisture to keep the soil from completely drying out. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to maintain well-draining soil conditions to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vachellia erioloba thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow well. It's adapted to the harsh sunlight of arid regions, so it performs best in environments where it can receive abundant natural light throughout the day. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and flowering occur under full sun exposure. Ensure the plant is positioned in a location where it won't be overshadowed by larger trees or structures, as this can lead to leggy growth and reduced vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vachellia erioloba should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the plant's health. Additionally, remove any branches that cross or rub against each other to prevent damage. If necessary, shape the canopy for aesthetic reasons or to improve air circulation by thinning out dense growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize potential injury or infection to the tree. Pruning should be done sparingly to maintain the tree's natural form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Camel Thorn","description":"Vachellia erioloba (camel thorn, giraffe thorn) is a tree of southern Africa in the family Fabaceae. Its preferred habitat is the deep dry sandy soils in parts of South Africa, Botswana, the western areas of Zimbabwe and Namibia. It is also native to Angola, south-west Mozambique, Zambia and Swaziland. The tree was first described by Ernst Heinrich Friedrich Meyer and Johann Franz Drège in 1836. The camel thorn is a protected tree in South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Camel Thorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia erioloba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19713,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heliotropium arboreum, commonly known as the turnsole or heliotrope shrub, thrives best in moderately moist soil. Water your Heliotropium arboreum when the top few inches of the soil feel dry to the touch. During warmer months, you might need to water more frequently, while in cooler seasons, reduce the watering frequency. Be careful not to let the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this can stress the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heliotropium arboreum prefers full sun conditions for optimal growth and flowering. Aim to provide your plant with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, if you live in a region with intense afternoon sun, providing some light shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent leaf scorch. In indoor settings, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. Adequate sunlight is crucial for this plant to produce its characteristic beautiful blooms and maintain vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heliotropium arboreum helps maintain its shape and encourages dense, bushy growth. During the growing season, water the plant regularly but allow the soil to dry out slightly between watering. Overwatering can lead to bulb rot, especially in water-retentive soils. It's crucial to reduce watering once flowering ends, typically at the end of spring or early summer, as the plant enters dormancy. During dormancy, the plant should be kept dry. The general advice is to provide just enough moisture to prevent shriveling of the bulbs but not enough to encourage growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lachenalia punctata thrives in environments with plenty of bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, especially during the morning or late afternoon. If the plant is grown indoors, position it near a window with filtered light to avoid the harsh midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. When outdoors, it does well in lightly shaded areas that receive a few hours of direct sunlight per day. Ensuring the plant receives sufficient light will aid in flower production and overall health, while too much shade can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lachenalia punctata is relatively straightforward due to its seasonal nature. After the flowering season, you should remove spent flowers to prevent seed formation and to tidy the plant. This process helps direct energy back into the bulb for the next growing season. Once the foliage begins to yellow and dry out, it can also be trimmed back as the plant enters dormancy. It's crucial not to cut the foliage while it remains green since it is photosynthesizing and feeding the bulb. Providing the right amount of light ensures its optimal growth and health, preventing any light-related stress or damage to the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Korthalsella salicornioides is not overly complex. Given that this plant is semi-parasitic and relies on another host, minimal pruning is usually needed. However, to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth, occasionally trim back overly long stems or any that appear dead or unhealthy. Pruning is best done in the growing season to help the plant recover more quickly, using sterilized pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease.
