Ensure proper airflow to prevent mold, and consider refrigeration at high humidity levels to extend its freshness."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sparassis radicata typically grows in shaded, forested environments on decaying hardwoods, particularly conifers. It's important to avoid direct sunlight, as excessive light and heat can dry out the fungus and hinder its growth. Providing conditions that mimic the understory of woodlands will support its development, keeping conditions cool and damp."},{"type":"pruning","description":"While Sparassis radicata is typically foraged rather than cultivated, if you are dealing with a wild specimen or attempting cultivation, there's no traditional pruning like with plants. However, it is important to gently clean the mushroom by removing dirt or debris. Use a soft brush or cloth to remove impurities, and trim away any damaged or decayed parts with a clean, sharp knife to prevent spoilage. When storing, ensure any cut or damaged sections are addressed to maintain freshness and quality for consumption."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Western cauliflower mushroom","description":"Sparassis (also known as cauliflower mushroom) is a genus of parasitic and saprobic mushrooms characterised by their unique shape and appearance. The plant benefits from dappled sunlight, similar to what it would receive in its natural understory habitat. If kept indoors, ensure it gets enough light by supplementing with a grow light during the darker months to maintain its growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Trochodendron aralioides should be done minimally since it naturally has a pleasing shape. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts. Avoid pruning heavily as this can stress the plant and lead to reduced growth. Regular pruning is not necessary unless shaping is desired, and always sanitize tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cartwheel Tree","description":"Trochodendron aralioides, sometimes colloquially called \"wheel tree\", is a flowering plant and the sole living species in the genus Trochodendron, which also includes several extinct species. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight each day for optimal growth and vibrant foliage. In cooler climates, providing more direct sunlight can help support its growth. Indoor specimens may need to be placed near a bright window but avoid direct afternoon sun which can be too intense, especially through glass."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coprosma rhamnoides is best done in early spring just as new growth begins. Use sharp, clean tools to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthier growth. Light pruning can help maintain the desired shape and size, and encourage bushier growth by cutting back longer stems to a set of leaves or a node. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can reduce the number of blooms and berries it produces. Regular pruning helps the plant maintain a tidy appearance and promotes rejuvenation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Twiggy coprosma","description":"Coprosma rhamnoides, also known as twiggy coprosma or red-currant coprosma is an endemic shrub in New Zealand. Ensure the plant base does not sit in water to prevent bulb rot. In the dormant period, particularly during summer, the watering can be reduced significantly as the plant's need for moisture decreases. Monitoring the garden’s natural rainfall is crucial, adjusting additional watering accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hyacinthoides × massartiana thrive best in partial sun to partial shade conditions. They can tolerate full shade, though blooms may be less profuse. Avoid overly sunny and hot locations, particularly during the afternoon, as excessive heat and light can stress and dry out the plant. These adaptable plants are often successfully grown under deciduous trees where filtered light reaches the plants throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hyacinthoides × massartiana involves mainly cutting back the flower stems once they have completed blooming. Deadheading spent blooms helps to divert energy back to the bulb, promoting healthier growth. Do not remove the leaves while they are still green since the foliage helps in photosynthesis, nourishing the bulb for the next year's growth. Leaves should naturally wither and yellow before being pruned back at the base. Removing dead foliage also helps to maintain a tidy appearance and ensures better health of the plant in the long term."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Hybrid bluebell","description":"Hyacinthoides × massartiana is a hybrid species produced by crosses between the common bluebell, H. non-scripta and the Spanish bluebell, H. hispanica. Ensure the soil remains consistently damp without becoming waterlogged. It is vital to maintain high humidity levels, especially in drier areas. Using mulch can help retain soil moisture. Water the plant deeply when the topsoil begins to dry out. However, avoid standing water, as this can lead to root rot. During mid-summer, when evaporation rates are high, more frequent watering might be necessary. Drainage is crucial, so amend the soil with organic matter if needed to improve water retention capabilities."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalmia polifolia prefers partial shade to full sun. When planting, select a location with dappled sunlight, like under the canopy of taller trees, to mimic its natural habitat and ensure balanced growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Kalmia polifolia during early spring just before the onset of new growth. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent infections and encourage healthy growth. Light pruning can be used to shape the plant and keep it compact. If the plant becomes overly dense, thin selectively to improve air circulation, which can help prevent fungal diseases. Deadheading spent flowers can also promote better blooming in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swamp Laurel","description":"Kalmia polifolia, previously known as Kalmia glauca and commonly called bog laurel, swamp laurel, or pale laurel, is a perennial evergreen shrub of cold acidic bogs, in the family Ericaceae. Be cautious not to over-water, as this can lead to root rot. Consider pruning in the spring or early summer to support the plant's natural growth cycle. Minimal pruning is required otherwise, as this fern does not generally become overly bushy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lance Fern","description":"Loxogramme dictyopteris, commonly known as lance fern, is a species of fern found in New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["Lance Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Loxogramme dictyopteris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Consider misting the leaves frequently or placing a humidifier nearby to maintain adequate moisture levels, especially during drier months. Additionally, during periods of active growth in spring and summer, increase watering frequency, while during winter, ensure the soil doesn't dry out completely but decrease watering slightly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Adiantum cunninghamii thrives in bright, indirect light. Be gentle in handling as its leaves are delicate and sensitive. Initial growth can be sparse, so patience is essential. Additionally, avoid over-pruning, which can stress the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19524,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus ampelos requires a balanced watering routine. Ensure the soil remains evenly moist, but not waterlogged. It's ideal to water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure your pot has good drainage. During the warmer growing seasons, you may need to water more frequently, while in cooler months, you can reduce the frequency. Always use room temperature water and, when possible, water in the morning to allow excess moisture to evaporate throughout the day."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus ampelos thrives best in bright, indirect light. Direct sunlight, especially harsh afternoon rays, can scorch its leaves, so it should be placed near a window with filtered sunlight or in a well-lit room. If the plant receives insufficient light, it might become leggy and show slower growth. During winter months or in spaces with limited natural light, consider supplementing with a grow light to provide the necessary light levels. Rotate the plant periodically to ensure even light exposure and balanced growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus ampelos helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. It’s best to prune in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation. Trim back any excessively long branches to maintain the desired shape and size. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts and minimize damage to the plant. Regularly prune to avoid overcrowding and ensure that light can penetrate through the foliage, promoting a healthy, lush appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"King's Fig","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["King's Fig"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Scale insects","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Air Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ficus ampelos"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensuring the area has some light, while prioritizing humidity and temperature, mimics the natural forest floor environment that many fungi thrive in."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a mushroom or fungus, Cortinarius rotundisporus does not require pruning like a typical plant. Instead, proper harvesting techniques should be employed. This involves carefully plucking the mushrooms when mature, usually by twisting and gently pulling them from the substrate, ensuring not to disturb the surrounding mycelium. This method helps to sustain future fungal growth and allows for continuing harvests if conditions are favorable."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"elegant blue webcap","description":"Cortinarius rotundisporus, also known as the elegant blue webcap, is a basidiomycete mushroom of the genus Cortinarius found in southern Australia, where it is found in eucalypt forests and rainforests. Maintaining a consistently humid and dimly lit area is ideal for promoting healthy growth, ensuring the fungus does not dry out and remains vibrant in color and texture."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Auricularia mesenterica is generally unnecessary as it is a fungus and not a traditional plant with leaves or branches. In periods of drought or particularly dry spells, it’s advisable to increase the frequency of watering to ensure that the grass remains lush and healthy. In areas with intense sun and high temperatures, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent stress and scorching. However, too much shade can lead to sparse growth and reduced vigor. Ensuring the plant receives adequate sunlight helps to maintain its growth rate and enhances its overall health, contributing to a dense, lush appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Lolium pratense is not typically required as it is a grass species used primarily for pasture or turf. However, mowing may be necessary to maintain desired height and appearance. Mowing should be done regularly during the growing season, ensuring that no more than one-third of the leaf blade is removed at any given time. This practice helps to keep the grass healthy and encourages dense growth by preventing it from becoming overly tall or leggy, which can lead to shading and thinning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"meadow fescue","description":"Festuca pratensis, the meadow fescue, is a perennial species of grass, which is often used as an ornamental grass in gardens, and is also an important forage crop.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["meadow fescue"],"pest_susceptibility":["Stem borer insects","Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Lolium pratense"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, in a controlled environment, maintaining humidity can benefit its growth. If grown indoors, it can be misted lightly once a week, particularly if the environment is dry. It's essential to avoid excessive watering or soaking, which can lead to decay, as lichens are adapted to live with minimal, often indirect water sources in their natural habitats."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chrysothrix caesia thrives in partly shaded to full-shade conditions, matching its natural habitat where it's often found growing on rock surfaces that receive dappled sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially intense midday exposure, should be avoided as it can cause desiccation and damage to the lichen. In indoor settings, it's best placed in a location that receives indirect natural light or use artificial lights designed for shade-loving organisms. Maintaining an environment with stable lighting conditions will help promote its optimal growth and vibrancy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Chrysothrix caesia as it is a lichen, which doesn't grow in the same way as traditional plants. However, if you notice any dead or overly shaded parts that aren't getting any light, you may gently remove them to promote healthier portions of the lichen. Since lichens grow slowly, regular pruning is not needed, but you should monitor its condition and remove any debris or dead material that may collect on its surface to maintain its health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Frosted Comma Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["USA","Europe"],"other_name":["Frosted Comma Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Chrysothrix caesia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19525,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helichrysum patulum prefers well-draining soil and moderate watering. It is crucial not to overwater this plant, as it is susceptible to root rot in overly damp conditions. Water the plant whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, allowing the water to drain well. Reduce watering during the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows down, being cautious to avoid letting the soil dry out completely for extended periods. Always ensure the pot has drainage holes to facilitate proper water flow."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helichrysum patulum thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. However, during the hottest part of summer, providing some light shade in the afternoon can protect it from leaf scorch, particularly if the plant is in a pot or container. If light levels are too low, the plant might become leggy and flower production can diminish. An outdoor location with well-circulated air and plenty of sunlight is ideal for its optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helichrysum patulum helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Trim back any dead or wilted stems and leaves with sterilized pruning shears. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to promote further blooming throughout its flowering season. This can be done by snipping the flower heads off at their base when they start to fade. For more significant pruning, wait until the late winter or early spring just before the growth phase begins. This is when the plant is dormant, making it less stressful on the plant to undergo pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Honey Everlasting","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Honey Everlasting"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Helichrysum patulum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18334,"attracts":["Waterfowl","Aquatic insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Potamogeton cheesemanii, commonly known as a type of aquatic pondweed, thrives in aquatic environments. Ensure the plant is fully submerged in water, as it derives its hydration from its surroundings. Regularly monitor the water levels and quality, keeping the water fresh and well-oxygenated. Replenish evaporated water with fresh, clean water to prevent stagnation, which can hinder growth. This plant can tolerate a range of water conditions but prefers clear, calm waters. Avoid using chlorinated water directly from the tap, as it can harm the plant. Instead, use dechlorinated or rainwater when necessary to maintain optimal health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Potamogeton cheesemanii prefers environments where it can receive bright, indirect sunlight or dappled sun, emulating its natural habitat. It typically thrives in ponds or shallow freshwater where it can access sunlight filtered through the water. Position your pond or tank where it can receive natural light without direct exposure to harsh afternoon sun to avoid overly warm conditions. If kept indoors in an aquarium, using artificial grow lights for 10-12 hours a day can help mimic natural light conditions and support healthy growth. Light levels should be adjusted based on growth patterns and leaf coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Potamogeton cheesemanii involves regular removal of dead or dying leaves and stems to encourage healthy new growth and to prevent decay that could affect water quality. It is commonly a low-maintenance plant in terms of pruning but benefits from occasional thinning to prevent crowding, especially in smaller ponds or aquariums. Use sterilized scissors to snip off any brown or damaged parts. Prune selectively to maintain the plant’s natural shape and promote new growth. Pruning is best done during the growing season when the plant is most resilient, typically from late spring to early autumn."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red Pondweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Red Pondweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Potamogeton cheesemanii"],"soil":["Aquatic","Clay","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18430,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"As a type of mushroom, Cortinarius austrovenetus, commonly known as the green skinhead mushroom, doesn't require traditional watering like houseplants. Instead, it thrives naturally in environments with adequate moisture levels in the soil due to rain or by being in a naturally damp environment, like a forest floor. If you are attempting to cultivate them, ensuring the substrate remains moist, not soaked, is essential. Overwatering can lead to rot, while under-watering may hinder their growth. Consistently maintaining a balanced moisture level by keeping the substrate damp will encourage healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As a mushroom, Cortinarius austrovenetus doesn't require direct sunlight for growth. In fact, mushrooms thrive in shady, humid environments reminiscent of forest floors where they naturally occur. Exposure to direct sunlight should be avoided as it can dry out the substrate and the mushrooms themselves. Instead, aim to replicate their natural conditions by ensuring they have a shaded environment with high humidity. If cultivated indoors, indirect light suffices but maintaining the right moisture and temperature is crucial."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mushrooms like Cortinarius austrovenetus do not require pruning in the way that traditional leafy plants do. Instead, managing the growth area by removing any decayed or old mushrooms can help maintain a healthy environment. This keeps the growing substrate free from decomposing material that might harbor pests or disease. Additionally, ensuring good airflow and space between the mushrooms helps in maintaining optimum growth conditions."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Green Skinhead","description":"Cortinarius austrovenetus, alternately known as Dermocybe austroveneta and commonly known as the green skin-head but also known as green dermocybe is an inedible brightly coloured green gilled fungus that naturally occurs in south eastern Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Green Skinhead"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Cortinarius austrovenetus"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18631,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Alectryon excelsus, commonly known as Titoki, requires moderate watering, particularly in its early growth stages. Ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged, especially during the warmer months when the plant's water requirement is higher. Once established, Titoki can tolerate some periods of dryness. Be cautious of overwatering, particularly if the plant is in a poorly draining soil, as this can lead to root rot. Reducing watering during the winter months will mimic its natural preference for drier conditions during the cooler season. Always adjust your watering routine according to climatic changes and soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alectryon excelsus thrives best in a position that receives full sun to partial shade. Ideally, select a spot where the plant can bask in the morning sun while being shielded from the harsh afternoon sun, which can be intense. In full sun exposure, the plant has more robust growth and produces a greater quantity of its distinctive red fruits. If growing in a region with particularly high temperatures, some mid-afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. While Titoki can tolerate partial shade, sufficient sunlight is crucial for its optimal development and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Alectryon excelsus is mainly undertaken to maintain its shape and health. It is best to prune after the flowering season, typically in late summer or early autumn. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent them from affecting the rest of the plant. Light trimming can encourage bushier growth, but avoid severe pruning as this can stress the plant. Focus on maintaining an open center to increase light penetration and air circulation within the canopy, promoting overall plant vigor. Tools used should be sharp and clean to make clean cuts and prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tītoki","description":"Alectryon excelsus, commonly known as tītoki, is a shiny-leaved tree native to New Zealand, where it occurs in coastal and lowland forests. It is found throughout most of the North Island and from Banks Peninsula to central Westland in the South Island.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Tītoki"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Alectryon excelsus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19428,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Geranium incanum, commonly known as carpet geranium, is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers moderate watering. It's best to water it deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot as the plant does not prefer waterlogged conditions. During the summer months, it may require more frequent watering to keep the soil slightly moist, but in the cooler months, watering can be reduced significantly. Observing the plant's foliage is key; wilting leaves may indicate the need for water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Geranium incanum thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, aim to provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from becoming stressed. Insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms, so it's important to ensure that the plant gets enough light. When planting indoors, a sunny windowsill with southern or western exposure is ideal for providing the necessary sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium incanum is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems by cutting them back to where you see new growth. To encourage bushier growth, you can pinch back young shoots periodically. After flowering, deadhead spent blooms to promote further blooming. Regular pruning keeps the plant from becoming too leggy and improves its overall appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent any disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"carpet crane's-bill","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["carpet crane's-bill"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Geranium incanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19819,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cartrema americana, commonly known as the \"wild olive,\" prefers moderate watering. Allow the soil to dry moderately between waterings to prevent root rot. Water thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the active growing season in spring and summer, it may require more frequent watering, but it's essential not to overwater as this plant is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Reduce watering in fall and winter, aligning with the plant’s natural dormancy period. Ensure good drainage in the potting mix to avoid waterlogging, which can be detrimental to its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cartrema americana thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure optimal growth and fruit production. Morning sun with afternoon shade can also be beneficial, especially in hotter climates. While the plant is tolerant of partial shade, too little light can result in less vigorous growth and fewer flowers or fruits. During extremely hot summer days, providing some shade during the afternoon can help prevent leaf scorching. Position the plant in a well-lit area for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cartrema americana should be done moderately to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to enhance air circulation and light penetration. Lightly trim back overgrown branches to encourage bushiness and remove any suckers growing at the base. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. Regularly check for crossing branches and prune them to prevent damage and promote a neat appearance, keeping the shrub looking tidy and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American olive","description":"Cartrema americana, commonly called American olive, wild olive, or devilwood, is an evergreen shrub or small tree native to southeastern North America, in the United States from Virginia to Texas, and in Mexico from Nuevo León south to Oaxaca and Veracruz.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["American olive"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Cartrema americana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19624,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gentiana arisanensis prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. During the growing season, it should be watered regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, but be careful not to let the plant sit in water, as this can lead to root rot. During its dormant period in winter, reduce watering frequency to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Always use lukewarm water, as cold water can shock the roots. Monitoring the soil moisture level and adjusting the watering schedule according to the temperature and humidity levels can ensure optimal growth and health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentiana arisanensis thrives best in partial to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive morning sun and have some protection from the intense afternoon sun, which can scorch its delicate leaves and flowers. If grown in hot climates, it benefits from dappled or filtered shade during the warmer parts of the day. For optimal flowering, ensure the plant gets a minimum of 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, in regions with less intense sunlight, it can tolerate full sun exposure. Adjusting the plant's position according to seasonal light changes can promote healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gentiana arisanensis typically involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and encourage reblooming. Deadheading, or trimming off the faded flowers, promotes more vigorous growth and prevents the plant from directing energy into seed production. In early spring, lightly trim back the foliage to shape the plant and remove any winter damage. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid introducing disease. Regular pruning enhances air circulation around the plant, which helps prevent fungal diseases and promotes sturdy, compact growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alishan gentian","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan"],"other_name":["Alishan gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gentiana arisanensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18531,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprosma rugosa is a hardy shrub that prefers well-drained soil and can tolerate dry conditions once established. Water this plant moderately, ensuring the soil remains moist but not soggy. During the growing season, regular watering is beneficial, especially during extended dry periods; however, be cautious of over-watering as it may lead to root rot. In cooler months, reduce watering frequency allowing the top soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Remember to adjust the watering schedule based on the plant's environment and season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprosma rugosa thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive full sun for at least six hours daily to ensure robust growth and vibrant foliage. In warmer climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense sunlight, which may cause leaf burn. Conversely, in cooler or less sunny environments, ensuring maximum sun exposure will promote healthy development and vigor. This plant is versatile and can adapt to various lighting conditions, but optimal sunlight results in the most vibrant foliage and healthiest growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coprosma rugosa helps maintain its shape and encourage denser growth. Typically, pruning should be done in early spring before new growth begins. Begin by removing any dead or damaged branches, cutting close to the main stem to promote healthy growth. Thin out crowded areas within the plant to improve air circulation and allow light to penetrate deeper into the foliage. You may also prune to shape the plant, keeping it compact and well-formed, but avoid excessive cutting which might stress the plant. Regularly check for and remove any weak or crossing branches throughout the year."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"needle-leaved mountain coprosma","description":"Coprosma rugosa, also known as the needle-leaved mountain coprosma, is a shrub in the coffee family, Rubiaceae, that is native to New Zealand. It is found in grasslands and forest margins up to the subalpine zone. C. rugosa bears small purple-white berries in autumn, the seed of which is widely dispersed by birds. It is considered a very hardy shrub and is suitable for hedging.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["needle-leaved mountain coprosma"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Coprosma rugosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18930,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Araujia hortorum, commonly known as the moth plant, requires moderate watering. It prefers well-drained soil and should be watered when the top inch of soil feels dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the pot has good drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water. During the growing season, which is spring and summer, keep the soil consistently moist but decrease watering in the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. Always consider your local climate, as humidity and temperature can affect watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Araujia hortorum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. In regions with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf burn and excessive water loss. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it gets adequate light. If natural light is insufficient, consider using grow lights to supplement. Consistent access to bright light will help the plant flower and maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Araujia hortorum is essential to manage its vigorous growth and to prevent it from becoming invasive. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems first, and then thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation. You can also trim back excessive growth to help maintain a desired shape and size. Regular pruning not only encourages a healthier plant but also helps to control its spread, especially in regions where it can become invasive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Moth plant","description":"Araujia sericifera is a perennial ornamental plant in the genus Araujia belonging to Apocynaceae family. This plant was described in 1817 by the Portuguese botanist Félix Avelar Brotero. The synonym Araujia hortorum is in more frequent use in New Zealand. Its common names include moth plant, white bladderflower, common moth vine, cruel vine and false choko.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Moth plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Araujia hortorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's essential to provide evenly moist soil, especially during its growing season in the spring and summer. In the winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. Ideally, the plant should receive morning sun with dappled shade in the afternoon. Most gentians do not require heavy pruning, but deadheading spent flowers can promote continued blooming and tidy the plant's appearance. Best practice involves pruning in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make precise cuts, reducing stress on the plant. Avoid cutting back too aggressively as this can hinder the plant's natural growth cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Gentiana sedifolia is a species of plant in the family Gentianaceae. In the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, only providing moisture every 3-4 weeks. Be cautious not to overwater, as yuccas are drought-tolerant and susceptible to root rot if left in overly moist conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Yucca flaccida thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its health and vibrant foliage. It can tolerate partial shade; however, insufficient light may result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. Outdoors, choose a location that offers ample sunlight throughout the day for optimal growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Yucca flaccida is primarily done to maintain its shape and remove dead or damaged leaves. It is best pruned in early spring before new growth starts. Using a clean, sharp knife or pruners, remove any dead leaves at the base of the plant. This not only keeps the plant looking tidy but also prevents the accumulation of pests and diseases. For taller varieties, you can also prune the main trunk to control height, but this should be done with care, ensuring to dry the cut properly to prevent infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Weak-leaf Yucca","description":"Yucca flaccida, commonly called Adam's needle or weak-leaf yucca, is a species of flowering plant in the asparagus family (Asparagaceae). It thrives in well-drained soil, which should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, more frequent watering is necessary, especially in periods of high temperature or strong sunlight. However, over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's important to let the top layer of soil dry out between waterings. In the winter months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the growing season. Water the plant deeply but less frequently to encourage deep root development. During the winter months, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Take care not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Using well-draining soil can help prevent moisture accumulation. Rainwater is preferred over tap water if possible, as ericas can be sensitive to high levels of dissolved salts and minerals in hard water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erica curviflora thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers to receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure optimal growth and flowering. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching and to conserve soil moisture. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure it is placed near a south or west-facing window that receives bright, indirect light. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so it's crucial to balance exposure suitably."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erica curviflora is important to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is immediately after flowering. Remove dead or damaged branches by trimming them back to a healthy node. Light trimming can help the plant retain its compact shape, but avoid cutting back into old wood as this can inhibit new growth. Pruning also helps promote more prolific flowering in the next season. Regular deadheading, or removal of spent flowers, will keep the plant looking tidy and can sometimes extend the flowering period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Water Heath","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Water Heath"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Erica curviflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regularly removing spent flowers can promote more blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"toropapa","description":"Alseuosmia macrophylla, the toropapa or karapapa, is a plant species in the family Alseuosmiaceae. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, it may require more frequent watering as it actively grows. In contrast, reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows. It’s important to monitor the plant's response and adjust its location as needed to maximize its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Seemannia sylvatica generally involves removing spent flowers and any unwanted or leggy growth to encourage bushier growth and prolong flowering. Adjust based on local climate conditions for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis sibirica is beneficial for promoting healthy growth and abundant flowering. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19430,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cussonia thyrsiflora requires moderate watering. It prefers soil that remains consistently moist but not soggy. During the active growing season, water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In the winter, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy and risks of overwatering increase. Always ensure that the plant is in a well-draining pot or planted in soil with good drainage to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture and reduce the frequency of watering during warmer months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cussonia thyrsiflora thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy foliage and flowering. In very hot climates, offering some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive adequate sunlight. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with a grow light to meet its sunlight needs. Ensuring adequate sunlight is crucial for the plant's robust growth and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cussonia thyrsiflora is generally minimal but can enhance the plant's shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. Prune in the late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any damaged or crossing branches to promote healthy growth. Also, cut back any branches that disrupt the plant's natural shape or are growing in unwanted directions. Frequent light pruning is better than heavy pruning, as this plant prefers to maintain its natural form with minimal intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Coast Cabbagetree","description":"Cussonia thyrsiflora, known as the Cape coast cabbage tree, or Kaapse kuskiepersol in Afrikaans, is a small evergreen tree in the Araliaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Coast Cabbagetree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cussonia thyrsiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19328,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scytinium palmatum, a type of lichen, requires specific moisture conditions to thrive since it naturally grows in moist environments. It's important to maintain a humid environment, mimicking the moist forest floors or wet rocks where it typically is found. Setting up a misting routine will help keep the lichen hydrated without overwatering, as these organisms do not handle standing water well. Using rainwater for misting can also be beneficial due to its lack of impurities. Ensure the substrate remains damp but not soggy to prevent the lichen from drying out, while avoiding waterlogging, which could lead to decay."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scytinium palmatum thrives in shaded or partially shaded environments, similar to those found in its natural habitat. Direct sunlight should be avoided, as it can desiccate the lichen or cause sunburn. A north or east-facing position where it receives indirect or dappled light is ideal. If kept indoors, position it in an area where it gets filtered sunlight or use grow lights designed for shade-loving plants. Consistent light conditions are important for its photosynthetic algae, which contribute to its overall health and development. Adjust as needed to mimic under-canopy forest conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Scytinium palmatum does not require traditional pruning like higher plants, as it is a lichen. However, it is beneficial to keep an eye on its growth and health by gently removing any discolored or dry parts that appear. This can be done by carefully pinching off the affected areas with your fingers. Cleaning debris around the lichen and ensuring good airflow can prevent issues and facilitate growth. Maintaining a clean environment will also help in monitoring the health of the lichen and prevent any infections or algae growth that might compete for nutrients."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Antlered Jellyskin Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Antlered Jellyskin Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Scytinium palmatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18236,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave mitis is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage in the pot or garden bed. During the growing season in spring and summer, water every 2-3 weeks. In the winter months, reduce watering to once a month, or even less if the plant is indoors in a cooler environment. Always check the soil moisture by inserting a finger about an inch deep; if it feels dry, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave mitis thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain optimal growth and color. However, in particularly hot climates or during peak summer months, some afternoon shade can help prevent sunburn on the leaves. If growing indoors, place the agave near a south or west-facing window that receives bright, direct light. If you notice the plant stretching or its leaves becoming pale, it may be a sign that it isn't receiving enough light and should be moved to a sunnier location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agave mitis generally involves removing dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant healthy and tidy. To prune, use sharp, clean shears and cut the leaves at the base, near the main stem. Be careful of the plant's sharp spines. Regularly removing dead leaves prevents pests and disease from taking hold. In general, agaves do not need much pruning overall. Also, remove any baby plants or \"pups\" if you do not want the plant to spread. Remember to wear gloves and protective clothing to avoid irritation from the sap."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mitis Century Plant","description":"Agave mitis is a plant species native to the Mexican states of Hidalgo, Tamaulipas and San Luis Potosí, referred to as Agave celsii in many publications.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Mitis Century Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Offset Division","Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agave mitis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Adjust the positioning depending on local climate conditions to suit the plant's needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diplacus kelloggii is relatively straightforward. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18735,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Metrosideros umbellata, also known as the Southern Rata, prefers consistent moisture in the soil, but it should not be waterlogged. Ensure the soil drains well to avoid root rot. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During summer, especially when it is warm and dry, increase watering frequency. In contrast, during the winter months, reduce watering as the plant’s growth rate slows down. It’s essential to adjust your watering schedule based on weather conditions to provide a more natural environment for the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Southern Rata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of sunlight per day to maintain its health, with more intensity being preferable. When grown in partial shade, it might exhibit slower growth and fewer flowers. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent any potential leaf scorch, especially during extreme temperatures. If planted indoors or in shaded garden areas, ensure the plant receives plenty of indirect light to sustain healthy growth and promote flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Metrosideros umbellata is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Trim back any dead or diseased branches using clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of disease. It's also beneficial to thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation within the plant. Regular pruning will ensure the plant doesn't become too dense, which can limit flowering. Be cautious not to over-prune, as cutting too much can harm the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Southern rātā","description":"Southern rātā (Metrosideros umbellata) is a tree endemic to New Zealand. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18933,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brunia noduliflora requires consistent but moderate watering. This plant is adapted to well-draining, sandy soils and is somewhat drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the pot or garden location provides adequate drainage. During dryer periods or when planted in containers, increase the frequency of watering to maintain moisture. However, be cautious not to let the plant sit in waterlogged conditions for extended periods. Adjust watering according to the climate and seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brunia noduliflora thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive several hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy growth and abundant flowering. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can help protect it from intense sunlight, which may scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window with ample light, or supplement with grow lights if natural light is insufficient. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even exposure on all sides. Ensure the chosen location has ample light to keep the plant vigorous and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Brunia noduliflora should be done after the flowering period to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged branches. Pruning helps to improve air circulation and light penetration to the inner parts of the plant, reducing the risk of disease. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant, leading to poor growth. Focus on trimming the tips to shape the plant or to control its size in landscape settings. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18237,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Syzygium smithii, commonly known as the lilly pilly or Australian bush cherry, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is crucial to ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged conditions, which can cause root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist. In the cooler months, you can reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows. Always adjust watering based on the local climate and season, allowing the topsoil to dry out slightly between watering sessions to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Syzygium smithii thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate a range of light conditions, but for optimal growth and flowering, ensure it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. If planted in a shadier spot, the plant may grow more slowly and produce fewer flowers. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive sun, which might cause leaf burn. Adjust the sunlight exposure based on your specific climate to ensure healthy growth and prolific flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Syzygium smithii is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting dense growth. The best time to prune is after the flowering period, typically in late spring or early summer. This will encourage a second flush of growth and enhance the plant's overall appearance. Use sharp, sterile pruning tools to remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Also, trim back any excessively long or unruly branches to maintain the desired shape. Regularly removing spent flowers can improve appearance and reduce the chance of diseases like mildew affecting the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Lilly Pilly","description":"Syzygium smithii (formerly Acmena smithii) is a summer-flowering, winter-fruiting evergreen tree, belonging to the myrtle family Myrtaceae. It shares the common name \"lilly pilly\" with several other plants, however in New Zealand, it is commonly known as 'monkey apple'. It is planted as shrubs or hedgerows, and features: rough, woody bark; cream and green smooth, waxy leaves; flushes of pink new growth; and white to maroon edible berries. Unpruned, it will grow about 3–5 m (9.8–16.4 ft) tall...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Pink\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Lilly Pilly"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Psyllids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Syzygium smithii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19135,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nama demissa, commonly known as Purple Mat, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It's important to let the top layer of the soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as it is a drought-tolerant plant. During its growing season in spring and summer, water it more frequently, ensuring the soil stays slightly moist but never soggy. In the dormant months of fall and winter, reduce watering significantly. Always use well-draining soil and a pot with drainage holes to facilitate excess water flow and avoid waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nama demissa thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day to bloom optimally and maintain its vibrant foliage. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to leggy growth and fewer flowers. If grown indoors, place it in the sunniest location possible, such as a south-facing window. Gradually acclimate the plant to intense sunlight to prevent leaf scorch if moving it from a shady area outdoors for summer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Nama demissa is generally minimal, focusing mainly on maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18634,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aporostylis bifolia, an orchid native to specific regions, requires a delicate balance of moisture. Watering should mimic its natural environment, which often means keeping the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's essential to allow the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Using distilled or rainwater is recommended as these are less likely to cause mineral buildup, which can be harmful to orchids. During its dormant period, typically in the winter, reduce watering significantly to once every few weeks."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aporostylis bifolia thrives in dappled sunlight, akin to the filtered light found under a canopy in its native habitat. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves, leading to stress and damage. An ideal location is an east-facing window where the plant can receive gentle morning sun, or a spot with a light shade cloth if grown outdoors. In darker periods, such as winter, you can move the plant to a brighter spot to compensate for the shorter and often dimmer days, ensuring it continues to receive adequate light for growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Aporostylis bifolia, like other orchids, is primarily focused on maintaining health rather than shaping the plant. After flowering, the flower spike can be cut back to the base once it has completely died back, as this prevents any unnecessary energy expenditure from the plant. Regularly check for and remove any dead or yellowing leaves to keep the plant healthy and reduce the risk of disease. Ensure that any cutting tools used are sterilized to prevent infection. Avoid over-pruning, as orchids grow slowly and need their leaves for photosynthesis."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Odd Leaved Orchid","description":"Aporostylis is a genus of flowering plants from the orchid family, Orchidaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19431,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gladiolus rogersii plants thrive in well-drained soil and require moderate watering. During the growing season, water them thoroughly once a week, ensuring the soil does not become waterlogged. It's important to let the topsoil dry out slightly between watering sessions to prevent root rot. Reduce watering as the plant naturally dies back after flowering in late summer to early fall. Be mindful of your climate; if experiencing heavy rainfall, additional watering may not be needed. Water sparingly during dormancy in winter, particularly in colder regions with low precipitation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gladiolus rogersii prefers full sun to ensure optimal growth and flowering. Place them in a location that receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, reduced sun exposure may lead to fewer blooms and less vigorous growth. In hotter climates, a location with morning sun and afternoon shade can prevent the plant from overheating. If grown indoors, place them near a south or west-facing window, and consider using grow lights if natural sunlight is insufficient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gladiolus rogersii is essential for maintaining its health and encouraging robust growth in subsequent seasons. Remove spent flower spikes after flowering, cutting them back to the base to direct the plant's energy towards its corms for next year's growth. Leave the foliage intact until it becomes yellow or brown in late autumn; this allows the plant to photosynthesize and store energy. Once the foliage has died, gently remove it. For densely packed or crowded clumps, divide them during dormancy to prevent overcrowding and promote healthier flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Riversdale Bluebell","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Riversdale Bluebell"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Thrips","Fungal rot"],"propagation":["Corm-based propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gladiolus rogersii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18831,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Streblus banksii, commonly referred to as \"thistle,\" requires careful watering to thrive. This plant prefers consistently moist soil, but it's important to avoid waterlogged conditions which can lead to root rot. Watering should be done when the top inch of the soil feels dry. During the growing season, it might require more frequent watering, but in winter, reduce watering to prevent over-saturation. Using well-draining soil can help maintain the right moisture balance. Always ensure proper drainage holes in pots to prevent water accumulation at the bottom."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Streblus banksii thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sun, especially in the morning, but it's best to avoid harsh, midday sun which can scorch the leaves. If the plant is kept indoors, place it near a window that receives plenty of light. However, if the light is too intense, consider using a sheer curtain to diffuse the sun’s rays. Outdoors, it should be planted in a spot that receives filtered sunlight through taller plants or structures. Ensuring the right light conditions will help it maintain its lush foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Streblus banksii is essential to encourage bushier growth and maintain the desired shape. Regular pruning should be done to remove dead or damaged branches, which helps prevent disease and promotes healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts just above leaf nodes or back to the main stem. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. Light, regular trimming throughout the growing season can also manage size and shape effectively."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Large-leaved milk tree","description":"Streblus banksii, commonly known as the large-leaved milk tree, is a species of plant in the family Moraceae that it endemic to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Large-leaved milk tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Streblus banksii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
